---

To run the tests, use:

```
./scripts/run-tests.sh
```

Available options:
- `-w` (watch mode)
- `-c` (coverage)
- `-u` (update snapshots)
- `-f` (filter tests, e.g. `-f FullCalendar`)

For example:
```
./scripts/run-tests.sh -w -c
```

nds up listening on. If true will be set to 51204. Use '--help --api' for more info.

on, use --no-isolate (default: true)
  --globals                                             Inject apis globally

abled (default: false). Use '--help --browser' for more info.
  --pool <pool>                                         Specify pool, if not running in the browser (default
: forks)

owser (default: node)

  --logHeapUsage                                        Show the size of heap for each test when running in 
node

ult: !process.env.CI)
  --dangerouslyIgnoreUnhandledErrors                    Ignore any unhandled errors that occur
  --shard <shards>                                      Test suite shard to execute in a format of <index>/<
count>

fault: false)
  --sequence <options>                                  Options for how tests should be sorted. Use '--help 
--sequence' for more info.
  --inspect [[host:]port]                               Enable Node.js inspector (default: 127.0.0.1:9229)  
  --inspectBrk [[host:]port]                            Enable Node.js inspector and break before the test s
tarts
  --testTimeout <timeout>                               Default timeout of a test in milliseconds (default: 
5000). Use 0 to disable timeout completely.
  --hookTimeout <timeout>                               Default hook timeout in milliseconds (default: 10000
). Use 0 to disable timeout completely.
  --bail <number>                                       Stop test execution when given number of tests have 
failed (default: 0)

(default: 0)

ts DiffOptions object. Use '--help --diff' for more info.

efault: false)

st workspace feature. This can be repeated for multiple projects: --project=1 --project=2. You can also filt
er projects using wildcards like --project=packages*, and exclude projects with --project=!pattern.

considered slow (default: 300)

ds (default: 10000)

---

Here are all the available test options for Vitest:

### Main Commands:
- `run`: Run tests once
- `watch`: Run tests in watch mode
- `bench`: Run benchmarks
- `related`: Run tests related to changed files
- `list`: List all tests without running them

### Common Options:
- `-u, --update`: Update snapshots
- `-w, --watch`: Enable watch mode
- `-c, --config <path>`: Specify config file
- `--coverage`: Generate coverage report
- `--ui`: Enable UI interface for tests
- `--testNamePattern <pattern>`: Filter tests by name
- `--reporter <reporter>`: Specify output format
- `--browser`: Run tests in browser environment
- `--silent`: Reduce console output
- `--retry <times>`: Retry failed tests
- `--project <name>`: Run specific projects (when using workspaces)

Would you like to try any specific command or option from this list?

---

---

The tests have run successfully with both coverage reporting and browser environment. All 7 tests passed successfully across 3 test files.

The coverage report shows the same results as earlier - overall coverage is at 3.44% with only a few files having any test coverage:
- `firebaseConfig.js`: 100% coverage
- `Login.vue`: 84.61% coverage
- `auth.js`: 68% coverage
- `userStore.js`: 26.28% coverage

The remaining files in the project have 0% test coverage, indicating that most of the code isn't being tested yet.

Testing in browser mode with coverage is particularly useful for Vue components since it provides a more realistic environment similar to where your components will actually run. This can help catch browser-specific issues while still providing code coverage metrics.
